(43) 227.3\st May, 1943.WAR CABINET.COMMITTEE ON MILITARY OVERSEAS SUPPLY REQUIREMENTS.Note by the Secretary of the War Cabinet.THE following minute has been agreed between the Prime Minister and thePresident: " Present estimates of shipping facilities indicate that there will be upto the middle of 1944 no surplus for any additional military operation thatmay become necessary.Searching and continued examination on a combined basis of civilianrequirements has set free a very large tonnage of shipping for military purposes.As the major portion of our combined shipping resources is employedon military work, notable gain for additional operations might be made bysubjecting military overseas supply requirements of both countries to animmediate scrutiny, conducted by appropriate officers of our two armies.The President requests the United States Chiefs of Staff, through theirnominee, to conduct (in Washington) this scrutiny, in consultation with theChairman of the Munitions Assignment Board.The Prime Minister will institute a similar enquiry in London by meansof a Cabinet Committee under the Chairmanship of Mr. Oliver Lyttelton,Minister of Production, with the Secretaries of State for War and Air, theMinister of War Transport and the Paymaster-General (Lord Cherwell) as members. The reports will be interchanged between the two countries, andwill be submitted to the President and the Prime Minister jointly andseverally."25552 Accordingly, an ad hoc Committee on Military Overseas Supply Require-ments is hereby constituted as follows : Minister of Production (Chairman).First Lord of the Admiralty.Secretary of State for War.Secretary of State for Air.Minister of War Transport.Paymaster-General.Secretary-Brigadier Jacob, Office of the Minister of Defence. )(Signed) E. E. BRIDGES,Secretary of the War Cabinet.Offices of the War Cabinet, S.W. 1,31st May, 1943.
